Algorithms¶

The romans package uses various algorithms to analyze simulation data. The algorithms are implemented as plugins and include dimension reduction algorithms from the Python package scikit-learn and the deep learning package pytorch. Custom algoirthms are also available.

Further, the algorithms are implemented as plugins, so user defined algorithms can also be added. Command line arguments are used to pass parameters to the algorithms.

To see the availble options for a romans algorithm plugin, call the plugin directly with –help option, as in:

python -m romans.algorithms.reduction --help

Dimension Reduction¶

The dimension reduction algorithms are provided in the algorithms/reduction.py module. Command line options are given below.

usage: reduction.py [-h]
                    [--algorithm {PCA,incremental-PCA,Isomap,tSNE,auto-encoder,Umap}]
                    [--pre-process {standard,minmax}] [--num-dim NUM_DIM]
                    [--time-align TIME_ALIGN] [--whiten]
                    [--model-type {MLP,var}] [--epochs EPOCHS]
                    [--batch-size BATCH_SIZE]
                    [--MLP-arch MLP_ARCH [MLP_ARCH ...]]
                    [--num-processes NUM_PROCESSES]

Dimension reduction support for the romans tools.

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --algorithm {PCA,incremental-PCA,Isomap,tSNE,auto-encoder,Umap}
                        Dimension reduction algorithm to apply. Options are:
                        {PCA, incremental-PCA, Isomap, tSNE, auto-encoder,
                        Umap}.
  --pre-process {standard,minmax}
                        Preprocessing for dimension reduction. Options are:
                        {standard, minmax}.
  --num-dim NUM_DIM     Number of desired dimensions in reduction.
  --time-align TIME_ALIGN
                        Train reduction model per time step to given dimension
                        then align using Kabsch algorithm.
  --whiten              Whiten before PCA.
  --model-type {MLP,var}
                        Type of auto-encoder. Options are: {MLP, var}.
  --epochs EPOCHS       Number of epochs to use for training auto-encoder.
  --batch-size BATCH_SIZE
                        Batch size for training auto-encoder.
  --MLP-arch MLP_ARCH [MLP_ARCH ...]
                        Integers specifying size of hidden layers in the MLP.
  --num-processes NUM_PROCESSES
                        Number of processes to use for training auto-encoder.

Proxy Models¶

The reduced order proxy model algorithms are provided in the algorithms/proxy.py module. The command line options for the proxy models are shown below.

usage: proxy.py [-h] [--algorithm {LSTM}] [--LSTM-steps LSTM_STEPS]

Reduced order proxy model support for the romans tools.

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --algorithm {LSTM}    Proxy model algorithm to apply. Options are: {LSTM}.
  --LSTM-steps LSTM_STEPS
                        Number of steps to use in LSTM optimization.
